event_name: Southeast Asia becomes a "hot" investment target
Mexican Finance Minister Jes√∫s Silva-Herzog announces that Mexico cannot pay back its loans
description:
This kicked off the Latin American and Sub-Saharan debt crisis, which would require IMF intervention on a multinational scale. This period was the first time the IMF implemented structural adjusment programs (SAPs) along with its loans.

This project focuses on the Asian financial crisis, and thus won't go far into the details of the 1982 debt crisis. But this crisis was extremely important for validating to the IMF its austerity programs and for establishing the IMF's power in bending countries to the rule of the dollar.

event_name: John Williamson publishes commentary on the "Washington Consensus"
Mikhail Gorbachev finally announces his resignation
description: Though it is just one event in a decades-long end to the Soviet Union that involved a coup in Russia, several declarations of independence from constituent republics, and the iconic fall of the Berlin Wall, Gorbachev's resignation cemented what had long been expected. The Soviet Union fell almost immediately in the weeks following, bringing an end to the Second World and the Cold War. Neoliberalism and Western capitalism had won.

This raised the perception of the U.S. as a hot investment opportunity, elevating the U.S. dollar's value. The raised perception of the U.S. for international investment and the peg of many Southeast Asian currencies to the dollar made Southeast Asian dollars more "expensive" and thus less attractive for foreign investment

Thailand is hit by the largest speculative attack in its history
Thailand takes the baht off of the dollar
Indonesia floats the ruppiah and faces the worst speculative attack of the nation's history
The Korean stock market experiences several jolts downward as investors pull out
Moody's lowers South Korea's credit rating from A1 to A3
The IMF and Korea reach an agreeement to a loan package.
description: Among other things, the loan agreement

event_name: President Suharto of Indonesisa resigns after several weeks of riots
Tens of thousands of Korean workers go on strike
description: Labor protections for Koreans, fought for in the 1996 strikes, were rolled back with the onset of IMF-enforced reforms. In many large corporations, mass layoffs as we traditionally know them did not occur, but some Hyundai Motor Co. threatened to bring layoffs of some 8,000 workers. Workers fought back.

The reverberations of the Asian financial crisis caused the price of oil to drop drastically, leading to several corporate mergers, the collapse of some U.S. hedge funds, and the Russian financial crisis of 1998.

event_name: South Korea pays its loans back early
